articles.headline: A Taliban Prize, Won in a Few Hours After Years of Strategy
articles.snippet: The capture of Kunduz was timed to the American withdrawal, a steady influx of insurgent fighters, a series of territory grabs and a campaign that took advantage of resentment of the government.
articles.abstract: The capture of Kunduz was timed to the American withdrawal, a steady influx of insurgent fighters, a series of territory grabs and a campaign that took advantage of resentment of the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban’s largest strategic victory of its long insurgency seemed to unfold in a matter of hours: At dawn a few hundred insurgent fighters entered the northern provincial capital of Kunduz from three sides, and by afternoon they ruled it.

articles.headline: Risky Strategy Sinks Small Hedge Fund
articles.snippet: Spruce Alpha fared worse than most in August, losing investors 48 percent of their money, documents show.
articles.abstract: Spruce Alpha fared worse than most in August, losing investors 48 percent of their money, documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was an upstart hedge fund that pitched large returns in periods of market turbulence by relying on a complex and controversial trading strategy.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Camp Is Making Moves to Check Joe Biden
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign appears to be worried about Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. making a run for president and has taken steps to lock down support for her bid.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign appears to be worried about Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. making a run for president and has taken steps to lock down support for her bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign, increasingly worried about the threat of a challenge from Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., is making a sudden and urgent effort to throw roadblocks into his path.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Pope Francis, the Kentucky Clerk and Culture Wars Revisited
articles.snippet: Pope Francis’ meeting with Kim Davis cheered conservatives troubled by his words on poverty, the environment and immigration, and dismayed liberals who said it negated much of the good will he had built up on his trip.
articles.abstract: Pope Francis’ meeting with Kim Davis cheered conservatives troubled by his words on poverty, the environment and immigration, and dismayed liberals who said it negated much of the good will he had built up on his trip.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a busy morning addressing a joint meeting of Congress and mingling with the homeless at an outdoor lunch, Pope Francis decamped to the heavily barricaded Vatican Embassy in Washington last Thursday for what Vatican officials billed as a brief afternoon siesta before his flight to New York, the second leg of his American trip.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: Putting Mobile Ad Blockers to the Test
articles.snippet: Two tests were carried out with ad blockers: one to measure how much loading times were improved and the second to study battery life.
articles.abstract: Two tests were carried out with ad blockers: one to measure how much loading times were improved and the second to study battery life.
articles.lead_paragraph: To block ads or not to block ads on your mobile device? That’s the philosophical dilemma facing consumers since Apple added support for ad blockers to its iPhone operating system a couple of weeks ago.

articles.headline: A Tradition for New Mothers in China, Now $27,000 a Month
articles.snippet: A custom known as “sitting the month,” when new mothers must stay indoors to restore their energy, has evolved into an opulent level of care.
articles.abstract: A custom known as “sitting the month,” when new mothers must stay indoors to restore their energy, has evolved into an opulent level of care.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Wearing gray pajamas and furry purple slippers, Li Rui relaxed on a couch in a plush suite where she had spent the last month since giving birth to her son — without ever going outside.

articles.headline: With Consumer Lenders Under Regulatory Glare, Big Banks Tighten Purse Strings
articles.snippet: The high-interest loan makers are facing heightened scrutiny, and the Wall Street financiers they depend on are pulling back.
articles.abstract: The high-interest loan makers are facing heightened scrutiny, and the Wall Street financiers they depend on are pulling back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumer lending firms that focus on borrowers with weak credit have done surprisingly well in the last few years. Many survived the financial crisis of 2008, the Great Recession, and even went on to post strong profits in the face of an onslaught of new regulations. Now, though, these lenders face pressure from an unlikely source: the big Wall Street banks that have long provided the financial underpinnings for their operations.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders’s Campaign, Hitting Fund-Raising Milestone, Broadens Focus
articles.snippet: The Vermont senator and his advisers, having raised about $26 million since July, are forming a battle plan beyond their immediate goals of winning Iowa and New Hampshire.
articles.abstract: The Vermont senator and his advisers, having raised about $26 million since July, are forming a battle plan beyond their immediate goals of winning Iowa and New Hampshire.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont still flies coach to his campaign events, sometimes taking the middle seat. He has not run any commercials, instead saving his money for a news media blitz this winter in Iowa, New Hampshire and the Super Tuesday states. His aides are only now preparing to conduct polls, to the consternation of some Sanders advisers who have hungered for data on his political challenges, like courting black and Hispanic voters.
